name: Toast (Comp Review)
htmlBanner:
Toast

The Toast component is a non-intrusive message display element used to deliver brief and important notifications to users.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

Toasts fall under the Alert Pattern and Alert and Message Dialog Pattern of the W3C guidelines. Definition of an Alert “An alert is an element that displays a brief, important message in a way that attracts the user's attention without interrupting the user's task. Dynamically rendered alerts are automatically announced by most screen readers, and in some operating systems, they may trigger an alert sound. It is important to note that, at this time, screen readers do not inform users of alerts that are present on the page before page load completes. Because alerts are intended to provide important and potentially time-sensitive information without interfering with the user's ability to continue working, it is crucial they do not affect keyboard focus. The Alert Dialog Pattern is designed for situations where interrupting work flow is necessary.” Definition of an Alert and Message Dialog ”An alert dialog is a modal dialog

Interaction

Auto dismissing and interruption It is also important to avoid designing alerts that disappear automatically. An alert that disappears too quickly can lead to failure to meet WCAG 2.0 success criterion 2.2.3. Another critical design consideration is the frequency of interruption caused by alerts. Frequent interruptions inhibit usability for people with visual and cognitive disabilities, which makes meeting the requirements of WCAG 2.0 success criterion 2.2.4

Keyboard Interactions

Not applicable. “Because alerts are intended to provide important and potentially time-sensitive information without interfering with the user's ability to continue working, it is crucial they do not affect keyboard focus. The Alert Dialog Pattern is designed for situations where interrupting work flow is necessary.” - W3C Alert Pattern

Guideline.html:
Overview

The Toast component is a non-intrusive message display element used to deliver brief and important notifications to users. It appears as a popup that fades in, displays the message, and waits for user dismissal.
 Toasts are designed to provide informational messages without interrupting the user's workflow.

Use Cases

The Toast component can be used in various scenarios to effectively communicate important information to users. However, it is important to note that in order to be accessible, vital information found within the toast should either be discoverable within the interface (like in a notifications section) or the toast should not be allowed to auto-dismiss without the user’s interaction.

Example of the component.

When to use

Notifications: Use the Toast component to display non-intrusive notifications or messages to users. This is suitable when you need to provide important information or updates without interrupting the user's workflow. Success Feedback: Implement a Toast to show success feedback after completing an action, such as successfully submitting a form, saving changes, or completing a task. Transient Messages: Utilize the Toast component for displaying transient messages that require user attention but don't require immediate action. Examples include warning messages, information alerts, or reminders. System Updates:

When Not to Use

Critical Alerts: Avoid using the Toast component for critical alerts or urgent notifications that require immediate user attention or action. In such cases, it is better to use modal dialogs, confirmations, or other prominent UI elements. Longer-term Messages: If the message or notification requires longer-term visibility or persistent presence, a Toast may not be appropriate. Consider using a notification panel, sidebar, or other UI components that allow users to access the information at their convenience. Complex Interactions: Avoid using Toasts for messages that require complex user interactions or input. If the user needs to provide input, make choices, or perform further actions based on the message, consider using a modal or dedicated dialog instead. Informational Overload:

Types

Toast

Basic toast component.

Toast - Stacked

Used to contain multiple toasts. Can be expanded or collapsed.

Behavior

The Toast component exhibits the following behavior: Appearance: Toasts typically appear as small, popups. Positioning: Toasts are commonly positioned at the top right of the screen, ensuring they are noticeable without obstructing the main content. Auto-dismissal: Toasts can auto dismiss after 5 seconds if the information displayed is supplemental and can be discovered somewhere else (like a notifications area). Success toasts are a good example of a component that can auto-dismiss. If there is no notification center, and the toast contains vital information for the user, it needs to persist until closed

Stacking

If multiple toasts are triggered, then we should use a stacked toast container. Expanded, it will show up to five toasts with a scroll bar to show additional toasts.

The newest toast should be on top, oldest at the bottom.

Truncation

The toast body copy should truncate after three lines of text. Try to keep the message within that amount. If more is necessary, use the “Show more...” text link. Text area should expand the size of the toast.

Responsive

The toast component doesn’t change width depending on the container’s size.

Dos and Dont’s

What are some use cases designers should pay attention to? Describe the do’s and dont’s for each particular use case. You can also use this section as a catch-all for guidance that can’t fit into other sections.

Truncation

Do keep copy to three lines of text. Truncate and use a “Show more...” link where necessary.

Don’t use too much text in your toast components.

Content

What kinds of rules do we have around the usage of content in this component? Include information on, if applicable, Casing, Headers, Labels, Label Length, Description, and Description Length.

Label

Define guidance rule here.
